2.text: (The silence is deafening at first. The slightest rise and fall of your chest ripples in your reflection in the fountain. Slowly, the rush of blood in your ears gives way to the trickle of water, the rustle of leaves, and most importantly—the voice that sounds in your head, clear and loud.)

3.text: Must I say the obvious? I’m asking you to name yourself! What manner of sorcery is this? What sort of trickery, what sort of—how utterly inconceivable!

4.text: Is this some sort of ploy to ruin my reputation? Or to—to erase my presence, diminish my standing while masquerading as me? Who would have the—the gall to puppet my body like some sort of—

5.text: [i]Why are you so silent?[/i] Say something! What is your house? Your name? Are you even a noble? Why are you doing this? I demand that you relinquish your hold on my body now!

6.text: (Before you can even get a word in she continues, spluttering along without a pause to breathe. Well, it’s not like she needs to anymore. The thought does not bring you much joy.)

7.text: Your silence is vexing. Absolutely vexing! I simply can’t understand what sort of sorcery has enabled this—this [i]theft[/i]. When is this? How long have you been steering around my body for? Oh, don’t answer. I’ll know soon enough.

9.text: …The fountain. This garden. I recognize this place; the royal gardens. Nighttime, the clothes you’ve hoisted onto my body—disgraceful, really, you’ve picked the wrong necklace to go with this design—the ruckus in the background.

10.text: This must be the ball. But that’s—I’m certain it had already passed—or was that another one? I…I don’t understand. Royal palace, gardens, ball… The shoes don’t match. Have you not had the mind to study fashion before your—

11.text: No, no, I don’t understand. Who are you? [i]What are you?[/i] What is it that you’re after? How are you doing this? You are just—

12.text: (Her voice rises in pitch, bouncing off the walls of your brain as a brief pause comes over her. Here is your chance to finally get a word in, before her tirade continues.)

13.options: Start arguing back.|Let her finish her train of thought.

14.text: How dare you—this is my body! What gives you the right to be saying such…! What kind of ignorant, incompetent, exasperating—

15.text: (Her trail of insults continues, and you have no choice but to tune out the spluttering words that fall apart in her frustration and anger. Patience, it seems, may be a virtue when it comes to situations like these.)

16.text: (Her anger slowly abates itself, but you never stop hearing tinges of hostility in her voice. If you wanted to cooperate, maybe it would’ve been better to let her words run their course. Ah, well, too late now.)

17.text: You just… I don’t understand. This situation is altogether too confusing. And worse so, I can’t move a single muscle. This is [i]my[/i] body.

18.text: Whatever you’re attending in my place, that is what [i]I[/i] should be attending. And you’re just some…some…

19.text: (The fight seems to leave her at that moment. It’s hard to tell what someone’s thinking without their face, but you try your best anyways.)

20.text: If you don’t want to be cast out of society for disrespect, then head back now. I’ll decide what to do with you after then.

22.text: What are you waiting for? Walk. I don’t have the patience to repeat myself for you.

23.text: (While her tone could stand to be nicer—not like you’ve had the chance to defend yourself in any case—she’s not wrong.)

24.text: (You’ve been gone long enough to likely make some wonder. And you’re the only one who can move, so with a mind jumbled with thoughts, you start walking back to the ballroom.)

25.text: (Cecilia is silent the whole way back, perhaps thinking. You, too, stay silent, unsure of how to even broach the topic. The time will come later. For now, you step back inside and hear the full force of a ballroom’s worth of attendees hit your ears. Your shared ears.)

27.text: I’m certain now, this is the Winter’s End Ball. I…this looks familiar.

28.text: What are you doing, standing around like an idiot? Start walking around. I need to see what’s happening.

29.options: Since you asked so nicely...|Okay.|I will. But not because you asked.

30.text: (As you skirt around the edges of the ballroom, she snaps at you.)

31.text: You don’t know how to dance, do you? Stay away from the center.

32.text: I won’t have you—whoever or whatever you are—make a fool of me.

33.options: Wasn't counting on it.|I won't. Really.|I wasn't going to. God.

34.text: (The hems of their dresses flutter with every turn, heels clicking against the floor. You stare in idle curiosity, drawn to the smiles that pull at the lips of the dancers. The music changes—Cecilia says something about the crown prince under her non-existent breath—and you see, in that moment, the sea of people part.)

35.speaker: A God
35.text: (It looks like divine providence. Beneath the chandelier, aglow in lights from all directions, is the most lovely girl you’ve yet to see in this world.)

36.speaker: A God
36.text: (Her alabaster skin remains unmarred and pure, her light hair fairy-like and gossamer smooth. An easy smile draws her soft lips into a smile. Never in your life have you seen someone so ready to be loved. So deserving of love, in a way.)

37.text: (Yeah. Yeah, she looks like she was made to be adored. She stands on her own, but doesn’t seem out of place as her curious eyes wander across the room, the dancers twirling beside her.)

38.speaker: A God
38.text: (You know this scene well, familiarity tugging at your memories. She’s none other than the protagonist of this game, the eternal good to the villainess’s eternal evil. Her first entrance into the world of the debauched, hedonistic nobles is through this ball.)

39.text: (You don’t even realize Cecilia’s fallen silent until she speaks up again.)

41.text: (The answer comes without a second thought.)

42.text: That’s Seraphina. The Saintess and the protagonist.

44.text: Yeah, of—oh, it’s hard to explain.

45.text: Then explain. Out with it. I’ve had enough of being kept in the dark.

46.text: No, it really is—and I’d have to explain why I’m here too, which isn’t for the reason you think—

47.text: Oh, enough about you. Tell me about whatever the hell that girl is.

48.text: (There’s a touch of hostility in her voice, but more than that… Is that tenseness you hear? There’s a hardness to her words and the slightest bit of a tremble as she spits out ‘girl’ with vitriol.)

49.text: (But before you can even begin, Seraphina turns—and sees you.)

50.text: (Dark black eyes, punctuated by a blinding white shine. For her, a mark of the divine.)

53.options: I think so.|Sure looks like it.|Hard to tell...?

54.text: You know her, don’t you? How do you know her? Who is she?

55.text: Like I said, her name is Seraphina—she’s the Saintess and the protagonist.

56.text: Yes, I heard—words that ultimately mean little to me. She looks…familiar. I’m not fond of it.

57.text: And “Saintess”? Don’t make me laugh. There hasn’t been a Saintess in Ulan for nearly a century

58.text: I’d much more likely believe that she’s simply another piece in this scheme you’ve concocted. I may be disembodied but I’m not blind—I can see it, [i]She knows you.[/i]

59.text: Wait, but she shouldn’t. You’ve—we’ve never met her before. This is supposed to be when she meets Cassius.

60.text: [i]Cassius?[/i] How is he involved with this girl? It makes absolutely no sense.

61.text: No, no, that’s the point! She’s going to be involved with him, because she’s the protagonist of an otome game.

62.text: A—a what? You need to start making sense, before my patience with you wears thin.

63.options: And I'm saying it's hard to explain!|Okay. Just let me try to explain.|Maybe if you'd let me finish then it'd make sense.

64.text: How would I know if you’re telling the truth?

65.text: For all I know, you could lie to me for whatever nefarious purpose you have in mind, the same purpose that led to you stealing my body.

66.options: I didn't steal your body!|That's not even the point.|Can you just let me talk–please?

68.text: (It feels like all too much: the blinding lights, the deafening chatter, the music, the scents, and the enraged voice in your head. And, above all, before your eyes is the protagonist of the game walking through the center of the room, headed right to you.)

71.text: (She breaks into a curtsey, all prim and proper. As expected of a charming peasant girl with nothing to her name but her ability to woo men in power.)

73.text: I—Seraphina? What? I swear, I recognize that name.

74.text: (Okay, so she recognizes—wait…[SeraName]? An inkling of familiarity sparks at the tip of your tongue, and you recognize it soon after. [SeraName] is what you named the protagonist of [i]Full Blossom[/i] before your death.)

76.text: My name is Seraphina. It is my pleasure to meet you, Lady Karmina.

77.text: (She takes a moment to curtsey, apparently eager to make your acquaintance. Only…why? She’s the heroine, meant to shine bright as the villainess grows envious in the shadows.)

78.text: Why in the world is [i]she[/i] greeting you?

79.text: (Cecilia seems almost stricken with panic, a hurried edge to her voice that strangles her words.)

80.text: After all, I hail from the countryside… I’ve only just yet entered noble society.

81.text: Is she playing the fool? Of course I know of—

82.text: This is the first time I’ve been to a ball. It [i]is[/i] rather grand, isn’t it? The lights, the music, the dresses…

83.text: Ah, mine? It was very generously gifted to me… What do you think?

84.text: Of course it looks good! When you’ve got the church practically begging to adorn you, to prove you’re aligned and well treated by them—

85.text: I fear it may stand out a little, after all. I’m not used to this kind of finery. But what about you, Lady Karmina?

86.text: You look so dashing in your dress. It really suits you!

87.text: Empty compliments from an empty-minded—are you listening to this drivel? Tell her to cozy up to some other noble who doesn’t mind entertaining a dumb blonde!

88.text: Listen to me. There is nothing good that can come out of listening to the likes of—of [b][i]her.[/i][/b]

89.options: Just calm down for a moment.|I'm so confused. What do you mean?|Give me a second to process all this.

90.text: You obviously don’t understand—when I say something, [i]I mean it[/i]. You’re in my body, so heed my words already!

91.text: Lady Karmina, won’t you say something? Please?

92.text: (Two voices collide, one in your mind and one right before you. They come together in disharmony and cacophony, each vying for your attention before you’ve had the chance to comprehend just one.)

93.text: (The overwhelming sounds of the ballroom don’t help, hammering into your ears as you juggle your fraying and fraught attention between Seraphina and Cecilia, each trying to make their mark in your mind.)

94.text: (Somewhere, there, your patience snaps. You need a moment—just a moment—of blessed silence to yourself.)

95.text: (Your breath catches in your throat, and instinctively you take a step backwards, trying to get ahold of your raging thoughts and messy mind.)

96.text: (And with that step backwards does the unthinkable happen. The chandelier, hanging peacefully above, chooses then to shatter and come plummeting down.)

97.text: (Your mind, in that moment, sees two things.)

98.text: (One, Seraphina stands right beneath the chandelier’s trajectory, and two, this is exactly what happened in Full Blossom.)

99.text: (Not everyone’s noticed the soon to be struck girl at the center of the ballroom, but you have. You see her, and she sees you.)

102.text: (Glass, flinging light to every corner of the room, comes hurtling down towards the dance floor. Anyone trapped beneath that would be killed in some miserable manner, whether bludgeoned by the chandelier’s metal chassis or pierced by glass shards.)

104.text: (Like the hero he is, a head of blond hair jumps out and sweeps the heroine into his arms. It all looks like slow motion, the chandelier’s slow descent and the way Cassius leaps to pull Seraphina into his arms and out of harm’s way.)

105.text: (She’s clutched tightly in his hold as the chandelier strikes the floor, shattering on impact with the [i]ksh[/i] of breaking glass.)

106.text: (The room draws a collective breath, silent in the aftermath of the accident. Cassius breathes heavily, and Seraphina in his arms looks up at him with her fluttering eyelashes.)

109.text: (But not for long—the clamor from the audience picks up immediately after and you snap yourself out of your stupor, but by then it’s too late. The sea of people around you part, until you remain alone standing before Cassius and Seraphina. You don’t realize, too dazed by the situation, until Cecilia points it out.)

110.text: [i]If you haven’t noticed, the entire room is staring.[/i]

111.text: (Her voice is strained, even icier than before.)

113.text: (Cecilia doesn’t have the chance to answer, because someone else does.)

114.text: (He comes storming over in the hushed silence. A head of bright red hair, back ramrod straight and eyes burning. You saw him not long ago—Esra, the tutor of Prince Cassius.

116.text: (Before your eyes, he steps in front of Cassius, who tenderly keeps a hold on Seraphina. In that moment, you feel like the audience right before a play. The actors have gathered, taken their spots, and speak the same words you know in your heart.)

118.text: Yes, I am. Thank you so much.

119.text: (The smile that comes across her face is nothing short of divine.)

120.text: I’m glad you’re unharmed. This, however, is unacceptable.

121.text: Why are you just standing there?

122.text: (The words coming out of your mouth are leaden, as you stay transfixed on what’s happening before you.)

123.text: What do you mean? I’m watching—

124.text: (You wrestle your gaze away from Seraphina, only to realize you’re utterly alone on this side of the room. A wide berth has been cleared away from every direction. If there were a spotlight, it would shine right on you.)

128.text: I had hoped it would all be an accident, but…

129.text: …You understand where I’m coming from, don’t you?

130.text: (Or so he says, but there’s a hardness to his jaw that belies his true thoughts. And more than that, you know. You know all too well what this situation is—how could you not?)

131.text: [i]This is… This is the scene where Cecilia calls out to the heroine, before she drops the chandelier on her.[/i]

133.text: Are you talking about me? Drop a chandelier? Who would be idiotic enough to do something so easily traceable in front of a room full of people?

134.text: Don’t ask me, how would I know? All I did was play that—

135.text: Your silence does you no favors, Cecilia.

136.text: Oh, this… Watch what you say now, if you don’t want this to be the death of us.

137.options: I have no idea what you're talking about.|Whatever you're thinking now–it's a misunderstanding.|You don't know what you're saying.

138.text: This situation is just…hard to look past. You’re standing here now, and the chandelier just so happened to fall, nearly crushing this poor lady?

139.text: Forgive me if I find such a series of coincidences difficult to believe.

140.text: I wonder, pray tell, what I should be thinking then.

141.text: I respect you, Cecilia, but as next in line for the throne I can’t let my personal opinions sway my judgment.

142.text: (He sets Seraphina gently on her feet, where she hovers just a little behind him, peeking out at you. The further away she gets, the more dread sets in. Sweat lines the back of your neck and your fingers twitch nervously.)

143.text: Oh, for—he’s going to call in that watchdog of his.

145.text: Don’t you see him? Look, with the red hair.

146.text: (Esra, from Cassius’s side, steps forward almost protectively.)

147.text: I’ll handle this, Prince Cassius. Don’t sully your hands on something as trivial as this.

148.text: That mangy… I’ll properly berate you for standing around like an idiot and letting it get this far later, but for now just prepare yourself.

149.text: Esra will go to any length to win an argument. If he wins, we’ll lose all standing with the nobles. [i]And I won’t let that happen.[/i]

151.text: Let me put this in perspective for you, Lady Cecilia.

152.text: Your reputation does you no honors. You have a history of resorting to various unsavory methods to achieve any means to an end, made worse by your engagement with the crown prince.

153.text: And now, of all times, you just so happened to be at the scene for what could’ve been a murder, speaking to the would-be victim, and you just so happened to take a step back just before the potential murder weapon fell?

155.text: (Before you can speak another word, a lone figure emerges from the crowd. Maverick hurries over to your side, standing beside you. He’d almost be comforting, if not for the same harshness in the lines of his face.)

156.text: Aren’t you being a little too hasty right now? I’m sure this was all a [i]coincidence[/i].

157.text: (He stresses the word coincidence a little too strongly. So much for a good defense.)

158.text: And he’s not making this situation any better either. I swear, all that buffoon knows how to do is swing a sword.

159.text: If you’re so interested in defending the family name, then put some more thought into your words. Who in this room would buy the idea that you really thought it was an accident?

160.text: Step aside, Maverick. I’m sure your sister can speak for herself.

161.text: Or are you that eager to disobey the crown prince?

163.text: (He gives you a sharp look, almost worried were it not for the general harshness of the line of his mouth, before he steps back and a little ways behind you.)

164.text: Good, at least he’s out of the way now.

165.text: This isn’t the end. They hardly have any evidence that’s not circumstantial. For now, all this will come down to is an argument.

166.text: You’ll have to defend yourself in front of the audience, keep your cool, and attack until his poise is gone. That’s the only way to win [social warfare].

168.text: Go. And if you humiliate me, I’ll make sure you pay for it, one way or another.

169.text: Let’s begin, Lady Cecilia. Or are you too afraid you’ll be put in your place?

argue.text: You’re not letting me get a word in anyways! Are you just going to keep repeating the same thing or are you going to listen to me?

train.text: (Your silence allows her to gather her thoughts, put them together.)

rejoin_1.text: Enough. This…[i]situation[/i], unorthodox as it is, seems to be something that can’t be helped for now. You’re trying not to be caught, right? I assume as much, based on the way you’re dressed and attending my social events.

fake_1.text: (As you step around the room, maneuvering through countless nobles, Cecilia continues muttering about “this lady” or “that lord.” It’s almost impressive, seeing her figure out the situation in real time. She picks apart the attendees, the dresses, the canapes.)

fake_2.text: (At least she’s not berating you the entire time anymore. As she continues muttering about “frills this” and “wine that,” your attention is drawn towards the glittering, gleaming center of the ballroom. Ladies are whisked around by lords, spinning and twirling like delicate little music box ballerinas.)

rename_branch.text: I’ve been waiting oh so long to greet you.

no_rename.text: I’ve been looking everywhere for you, you see, to finally greet you.

rejoin_2.text: I’m, well… You must not recognize me, Lady Karmina. I completely understand.

sassy.text: I might not, but I know someone who does.

rejoin_3.text: You have the right to speak, Cecilia, but I won’t allow justice to be hampered by insincere words. Especially not in the royal palace.

fake_5.text: Do you think people here are kind enough to wait for you?
